column1: Directors David Farrier and Dylan Reeve's documentary Tickled qualifies as one of those true stories that defies invention.
The title suggests a film about a harmless fetish, but this chilling documentary uncovers more emotional pain than physical pleasure.
The dark and twisted labyrinth at the heart of this story is thoroughly unexpected, and ultimately terrifying.
Anyone familiar with Internet shenanigans can guess the "twist" in Tickled long before the reveal. But that doesn't make the journey any less compelling.
A bizarrely gripping, oddly hilarious, and downright disturbing glimpse into a level of weird you didn't even know existed.

Though Tickled often overplays the extent of the corruption and threatening nature of its subject, it treats the subculture at its center with delicacy and respect -- and the mystery that propels it with journalistic energy.
...Tickled would've been better off as a short segment on 60 Minutes.
It's a fascinating tale, that is followed by the shorter addendum, The Tickle King, about what happened when the principals showed up to disrupt festival screenings.
Tickled runs a bit too long (at 90 minutes) and proves slightly unsatisfying in its denouement. The new, 20-minute tack-on, The Tickle King, helps somewhat and offers new, necessary details.
Tickled will sucker-punch you right in the guts. A must-see.
Directors David Farrier and Dylan Reeve's documentary Tickled qualifies as one of those true stories that defies invention.
The title suggests a film about a harmless fetish, but this chilling documentary uncovers more emotional pain than physical pleasure.
The dark and twisted labyrinth at the heart of this story is thoroughly unexpected, and ultimately terrifying.
Anyone familiar with Internet shenanigans can guess the "twist" in Tickled long before the reveal. But that doesn't make the journey any less compelling.
A bizarrely gripping, oddly hilarious, and downright disturbing glimpse into a level of weird you didn't even know existed.

Though Tickled often overplays the extent of the corruption and threatening nature of its subject, it treats the subculture at its center with delicacy and respect -- and the mystery that propels it with journalistic energy.
...Tickled would've been better off as a short segment on 60 Minutes.
It's a fascinating tale, that is followed by the shorter addendum, The Tickle King, about what happened when the principals showed up to disrupt festival screenings.
Tickled runs a bit too long (at 90 minutes) and proves slightly unsatisfying in its denouement. The new, 20-minute tack-on, The Tickle King, helps somewhat and offers new, necessary details.
Tickled will sucker-punch you right in the guts. A must-see.
One has to admire the tenacity, courage and skill of Farrier and Reeve to follow this story to its logical conclusion. I hope they come out of the lawsuits O.K.
David Farrier and Dylan Reeve's Tickled defies belief and almost description.
Tickled is a brilliant mystery film and simply has to be seen to be believed.
Tickled delves straight into the heart of the human condition, examining our motivations, passions and perversions, whether of sexuality or character.
A disturbing documentary about tickling that is not as funny as creepy.
Tickled is an unexpectedly engrossing documentary that's built around the hitherto unexplored (on film anyway) world of "competitive endurance tickling".

There's stranger than fiction, and then there's stranger than stranger than fiction. Tickled, the new documentary from New Zealand filmmakers David Farrier and Dylan Reeve, falls into the latter category.
They tell the story expertly, with the right mix of humor and fascination.
The story's spine is so magnetic that you're held tight until the quiet but conclusive finale.
The deeper they dig, the stranger the story gets.
It would be unfair to spoil the surprises in David Farrier and Dylan Reeve's investigative documentary Tickled, but the premise should be enough to draw you in.
More meaningfully, Tickled offers an anatomy of intimidation that feels particularly relevant for our post-Gamergate times.

With startling moments at every turn, this is a genuine jaw-dropper, a classic piece of investigative film-making as Farrier and co-director Dylan Reeve display tenacity and fortitude in penetrating a web of lies, manipulation... and tickling.
It's hard to explain how cleverly the film is structured without giving away crucial twists.
A very strange but utterly mesmerising documentary.
A fascinating piece of investigative film-making about a subject that is not nearly as innocuously fluffy as it sounds.
"It's unlikely you're going to come across too many documentaries this year with a yarn to spin as tangled and twisted as Tickled."
A gonzo doco for the new media age.
Like Stories We Tell or Dig!, Tickled subverts your expectations. Definitely strange rather than ha-ha.

Tickled starts out being a documentary about how funny-weird the internet is, gradually crosses the loose, porous line into how scary-weird it is, and proceeds down one particular rabbit-hole which has nothing reassuringly cuddly at the end of it.
Tickled is one of the strangest documentaries to see release in recent times, and while it offers some solutions it raises a lot of questions that cut to the heart of the human experience.
Farrier doesn't overlook the amusing oddness of such a strange corner of the internet, but treats the subjects of the videos respectfully.

Tickled is disturbing and deeply weird, but you have to hand it to Farrier and Reeve for bravely trying to put a stop to the bully tactics of the man behind it all. It's no laughing matter in the end.
A stranger-than-fiction voyage into that cultural abyss known as the internet.
[Farrier] leaves what's most interesting about the underground fetish in Tickled untouched.
New Zealand journalist, specialising in the absurdity of popular culture, David Ferrier investigates the corrupt underbelly of Competitive Endurance Tickling.
Believe me when I tell you that you won't pick the provocative, disturbing and utterly compelling places the doco will be going to. Especially from a seemingly innocuous start point.
It starts as a curiosity show and ends as a thriller
Intriguing, disturbing mystery at Core of "Tickled."
An amazing and disturbing documentary by David Farrier and co-director Dylan Reeve.
Your curiosity will be at a high from the start to finish. Expect laughter and a lot of cringing along the way.
Tickled is worth a look simply because it's a wonderfully told and singularly bizarre story.
... an example of investigative journalism at its finest.
Tickled thrums with the energy of All the President's Men, and is as much as conspiracy thriller as its fictional forbears.
The old cliche about truth being stranger than fiction rarely feels so apt.
Tickled is so weird, so unpredictable, it's hard to know how to categorize it.
Tickled is a solid movie. It's also incredibly uncomfortable or intensely erotic.

Tickled doesn't quite answer all of the questions it brings up... but it is a fascinating and disturbing descent into a particular online underworld that continues to confirm that the internet is a vast and mysterious place.
Tickled starts out as a quirky comedy but builds into something dark, menacing, and even profound.

On its surface, Tickled is about Farrier and Reeve's search for a truth about who's behind these tickle cells... But it's also, at another level, about how such a search becomes a truth of its own, documented and disseminated.
There are lessons to be learned here; hopefully, they will shine through the murk.
These are really stories about power, shame, and the law.
Like the activity of its title, "Tickled" is funny until it most decidedly isn't.
Not quite answering every question it asks, "Tickled" still opens a dangerous "can of worms" of stranger-than-fiction journalism.
"Tickled" is provocative stuff, but it's more compelling when working to define the sport and its players, finding its interests in gotcha journalism unnecessary.
The dangers of the internet have rarely been presented so convincingly.

It's hard not to get caught up in the movie's thrill of the chase, as Farrier and Reeve dig deeper and deeper for clues before finally pulling back the curtain on the person behind this fetish-filled Oz.
Chilling and inexplicably fascinating, Tickled is a looping left hook of a documentary; it'll knock you out, and you won't know what hit you.
The twists and oddities pile up in a narratively satisfying yet morally murky mess.
This New Zealand doc tickles the funny bone but also chills the spine. It delves into a goofy fetish that leads down serious and unsettling paths.

What starts off as a light-hearted, quirky portrait of a "competitive tickling" competition quickly turns into a deadly serious investigation about the destructive powers of the Internet and the perversity of those lurking behind its digital walls.

Investigation of the sport and its subculture leads Farrier and co-director Dylan Reeve down a rabbit hole of fetishism, fraud, blackmail, bigotry, and some truly menacing behavior. (Tickled gets scary!)
The potential for a wider narrative - cyber-harm - gets lost as his focus narrows down to a heavy-handed, as in anvils-for-hands heavy, and ineffectual revelation.

Though his lighthearted tone has difficulties keeping up with each new sinister discovery, Farrier has exposed in the least likely setting the network of power and money that preys on the weak with impunity.

What was meant at the start to be a humorous fluff piece about dudes who tickle each other for fun and profit turns into a mission: To find and reveal the elusive czar of this underground tickling empire and to expose its true intentions.

It's a documentary that for about one minute seems as though it's going to be as fey and quirky as its title. But far from a jolly little film about odd, harmless people, it's dark, weird and menacing.
It's best if you see it cold.
Their approach takes part in what might be called the Ira Glass Fallacy, mistaking detail for substance.
Creepy... Piquant picaresque.
This is one hell of a fascinating ride.
The sport of "competitive endurance tickling" is no laughing matter.
Shocking. Thrilling. And a little titillating.
Tickled is an instant classic, one that will appear on "Top 50 Documentary" lists forever.
"Tickled" certainly doesn't describe how I felt at the end of this fascinating documentary; more like thoroughly creeped out.
It is a case of good journalism and a weird and, until now, little known fetish that is the draw.
A surprisingly urgent film (about competitive tickling).
Simply delightful in just how stranger than fiction it manages to be.
When I saw Tickled at Sundance this January, I thought it was a fun trifle. In the months since, it's felt like a warning sign of the mediapocalypse.
Anything but fun, Tickled is a real bait-and-switch, but a highly effective and watchable one.
Tickled is near-impossible to take seriously, even as Farrier and Reeve's Nick Broomfield-esque bumbling blows the lid on a genuinely frightening individual.
The moviemakers craft a satisfying narrative while leaving the viewer with some questions; this is a movie that manages to be disquieting and entertaining simultaneously.
Head-spinning - and a mini-master class in investigative journalism, in an era that no longer prizes that costly undertaking.
What does homoerotic vanilla bondage have to do with you? A lot, it turns out.
A terrifically entertaining documentary about a strange, murky corner of the adult tickling world.

The movie draws you in with its eyebrow-raising look at an erotic subculture, then quickly escalates into a harrowing tale of alleged identity theft, online intimidation and American privilege gone dangerously awry.
"Tickled" opens a smudged window on a dark alley of contemporary life.
Farrier and Reeve do yeoman's work in getting to the bottom of Jane O'Brien Media, and the evidence they find constitutes an engrossing work of documentary filmmaking.
Tickled could have easily been a weird little piece of ephemera, but it instead evolved into a deeply felt crime thriller you have to see to believe.
It's astounding. It's also infuriating, another case of wealth corrupting justice.
Begins as a lighthearted look at the alleged sport of "competitive endurance tickling" and gradually turns into something much more disturbing.
Inspires many laughs throughout but, true to its subject, more and more of them are born of discomfort as it goes on -- part of you wants it all to stop even as you're amused.

As an expos, Tickled is a compelling, stranger-than-fiction procedural. As a glimpse at the creepier corners of the internet, it's a sobering snapshot of the dark side of digital anonymity in the 21st century.
Gunning to be the year's strangest doc, 'Tickled' takes a Dantean descent into a shadowy netherworld as bizarre as the ones in 'Eyes Wide Shut' and J.G. Ballard's 'Crash.'
There's no sustained effort to answer the first question any editor or J-school instructor worth his or her salt would ask: So what?
One of the strangest and most utterly engrossing documentaries of the year.
A fascinating detective story that comes highly recommended.
It's funny, it's compelling, and - as Farrier loquaciously states - "it's actually f--king creepy as f--k."
In its genial, low-key way, the film ... is a chilling account of cyberbullying, perpetrated on a disturbingly wide scale over many years.
Weird, funny, mysterious and controversial ... the further it digs the more surprising and strange it gets.
Tickled morphs from an offbeat caper to a disturbing expos on the dangers of cyberbullying.
